content:
Original:

Edited(added a new sentence):
It is guaranteed that there will not be two changes with the same position.

I've edited the statement based on the comment in the forum ( https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-insert-to-string/197073/21 ) and made other changes as well to clarify the rules:

Goal
* Original: Commit all of the changes to the given string so they wouldn't interfere with each other.
Revised: Apply all of the changes simultaneously on the original string (not sequentially on the string after each change). 

* Original: ("\n" should be replaced with a newline.)
Revised: After that, replace every occurrence of \n in the final string (including those originally present) with an actual newline.

Input
* Original: Next changeCount lines: A string rawChange that manipulates the string.
Revised: Next changeCount lines: A string rawChange that manipulates the string in the format of line_num|col_num|to_add, where:
line_num (integer): the 0-based index of the line to modify (after interpreting each \n in s as an actual newline)
col_num (integer): the 0-based position in that line where the text should be inserted (based on the original string, before any changes)
to_add (string): the text to insert

Constraints
* Original: s String of length ≥ 1
Revised: Length of s ≥ 1

* Original: rawChange = {Line number (int)}|{Column number (int)}|{String to add at the position (string)}
Revised: (deleted, moved to Input section and expanded)

Given the number of upvoted comments who didn't understand it to mean that the line and column numbers always refer to positions in the original string, the language "so they wouldn't interfere with each other" is not sufficient.

Note: please take the below with the tone of "intended to help you improve" and not as an attack.

I don't understand many aspects of this puzzle.

Let's start with the obvious, Test 1, same as example. Test data is:
Hello world
4
0|11|!
0|5|,\n
0|7| w
0|10|\n

After first step the string becomes:
Hello world!

After second step it becomes a two line string (or whatever that is):
Hello,
 world!

where the second line starts with a space.
Third command is to make a change at row index 0, column index 7. First line is of length 6, so not even with 1-based indexing would this work. If "\n" should be replaced only after last step, then row index in the input makes no sense at all. If "\n" would represent a single character and thus the first line is of length 7, then adding something AFTER it is impossible since that would contradict what EOL (end of line) represents. This most certainly means that the new characters won't land at the beginning of the second line, since that is the 1|0 command. Also please note that not a single software in existence let's you write something after the end of line character.

Furthermore, "rawChange = {Line number (int)}|{Column number (int)}|{String to add at the position (string)}" is not a constraint, that's exactly what the input is for. So I suggest to rephrase "Next changeCount lines:" to be "A string of the format rowIndex|columnIndex|addendum", where ...", you explain all 3 variables (make it yellow). Also the pipe symbol should be blue as that is a fix separator. If you don't like it like this you can specify the 3 variable names and say "that are separated by |". If you look at a few tens of CG made puzzles you will see many examples of both formatting.

The Output section should be something along the lines of "the string after making all changes". Manipulation is a strong word to use for adding a few characters to a string.

For the constraint "s String of length ≥ 1", that's sort of a given, the goal is to have a maximum value, so more like "length of s <= 7", where  7 is an actual number based on tests and validators (I'm lazy to count).

As a bonus, as a software engineer you should always avoid one character variable names, so if you can find a better fitting name than "s" it would be awesome.

The description part should be much more descriptive. Always specify that you are using 0-based indexing. Specify that the "\n" string represents a special character. Specify if that should be replaced immediately.

The current version of this puzzle is more a reverse engineering puzzle than a "normal" one, which is not the goal of puzzles in this section.

And lastly the tag "Strive for Simplicity" is incorrect. There is literally no way to make the solution simpler or more complicated, the runtime difference of solutions in the same language should be in the range of nanoseconds I guess.

This is a pain.  PHP ...so the input changes \n into \\n, and for some odd reason a strtr() to replace them doesn't seem to work.  The output is always screwed up.  checking the ord() of each character does work ... but I'm not gonna bother converting the weird input to do a workaround.  you should have used {EOL} or </br> or something like that.  And mb_str_split() comes up with an error even though the function prototype is in the editor.  So I hate it.  if I'm wrong, let me know ... and I'll resubmit. smh.

very interesting problem, fun to solve...
Nice and Fun!!

after the "0|5|,\n", there are two lines, right?
how to add "0|7| w" in the first line, which only have 6 columns?
I think this puzzle is very neat and should serve well as an entry level quiz.
Nice concept. Definitely and easier puzzle that I could see coming across in CoC.
Fun and clear

coding

as a solution.
Please give the string before the changes, but it's a nice (very) easy puzzle. Maybe better for a coc
Nice puzzle easy to understand and interesting to resolve ! As Nicola said, maybe the sentence should be given before changes to be done

Easy puzzle, we can add more escape chars to make it more practice wize:
\a	Alert (bell, alarm)
\b	Backspace
\f	Form feed (new page)
\n	New-line
\r	Carriage return
\t	Horizontal tab
\v	Vertical tab
\'	Single quotation mark
\"	Double quotation mark
\?	Question mark
\\	Backslash

You should give the string before the changes to be made.
I don’t understand the third change.
It’s an easy puzzle (maybe it might be a CoC), not a hard one.
Do you think I should submit it as a CoC instead of a Classic Puzzle?

"Commit all of the changes to the given string so they wouldn't interfere with each other."

You need to add "0|7| w" like "0|5|,\n" never happened.

Thanks for approving! 
Just wondering, how did you involve regex in your solution?
I don't really understand... Are you having trouble parsing the rawChanges? That's just basic string manipulation.

You seem to have the wrong idea about how the puzzle works, similar to how another comment misunderstood it.

"Commit all of the changes to the given string so they wouldn't interfere with each other."

You need to add "0|7| w" like "0|5|,\n" never happened.

The "Strive for Simplicity" is because the solution is very simple, but I've seen many people try to solve it in very complicated manners. Also, I don't think this tags relates to the runtime difference between solutions.

And regarding the formatting, I'll checkout different challenges' formatting when I have the time.

<?php
$all=stream_get_contents(STDIN);
error_log($all);
error_log(var_export($all,true));

What you think you are getting versus what you actually get. '\' is special:
Hello world
4
0|11|!
0|5|,\n
0|7| w
0|10|\n
'Hello world
4
0|11|!
0|5|,\\n
0|7| w
0|10|\\n'

",,,\n"\n-
5
0|1|You''ve gotta dance like there's nobody watching
0|2|\nLove like you'll\nnever be hurt
0|3|\nSing like there's nobody listening
1|0|And live like it's heaven on earth.
2|1| William W. Purkey
'",,,\\n"\\n-
5
0|1|You\'\'ve gotta dance like there\'s nobody watching
0|2|\\nLove like you\'ll\\nnever be hurt
0|3|\\nSing like there\'s nobody listening
1|0|And live like it\'s heaven on earth.
2|1| William W. Purkey'

I still don't understand what you are complaining about.
Are you having trouble with PHP? If so, how does your issue with PHP relates to the challenge?

Or are you saying writing '\n' instead of a newline is bad? Because having '\n' that the user then have to replace with a newline is very reasonable and is much less confusing than actually putting a newline there.
acctually no need of regex, a split will do the job. but to deal with "\\" in regex is fun.

ok, clear now. tks.

what if I keep inserting in the same position twice? which insertion comes first?
seems it is not involved in the cases, but still a relevant problem.

"Commit all of the changes to the given string so they wouldn't interfere with each other."

This language may need changing.

To me, it reads as though you should commit every change, so that the SUBSEQUENT changes can be applied.  This would be how edits to a document work... and it's what most people will expect.

Instead, we have a strange situation where :
1. newlines are added, and converted, but are ignored
2. pre-existing newlines are respected
so...
3. Number of lines is fixed until output converts newlines

The description does not adequately convey this, IMO.
